newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: New initiatives aimed at APEC's entrepreneurs.
newsitem.headline: New initiatives aimed at APEC's entrepreneurs.

text.p: Trade ministers of 18 Asia Pacific economies are expected to approve projects aimed at helping small and medium-sized companies compete in a regional free trade regime, an APEC official said on Tuesday.

Melito Salazar of the Philippines, chairman of a committee on small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), said several new initiatives would be presented to ministers meeting in the central Philippine city of Cebu on Thursday and Friday.
"APEC is really designed for the small and medium enterprises. The process of liberalisation in trade and investment will provide great opportunities for the SMEs," Salazar told a news conference.
"These small and medium enterprises must be assisted to be able to improve their capability to grasp the opportunities being presented," he added.
SMEs comprise 90 percent of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) member economies which produce more than half of the world's traded goods, officials said.
They also contribute 30 to 60 percent of APEC members' gross domestic product and account for 35 percent of the region's exports, they added.
Salazar declined to specify the proposed projects.
APEC aims to bring down trade tariffs and liberalise investment by year 2020 for developing countries and 2010 for developed countries.

Its members are Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Korea, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, the Philippines, Taiwan, Thailand, Singapore and the United States.
